occurrences.line_text: And oft for dread of hurt would him aduise,
And oft refreshed, battell oft renue:
And oft refreshed, battell oft renue:
So oft as he through his owne foolish pride,
Him oft and oft I askt in priuitie,
Him oft and oft I askt in priuitie,
Thy life shut vp, for death so oft did call;
As carefull Nourse her child from falling oft does reare.
Of that deare Lord, who oft thereon was fownd,
Death better were, death did he oft desire,
Yet he it oft aduentur'd to inuade.
That oft they did lament his lucklesse state,
Oft had he seene her faire, but neuer so faire dight.
Which though he hath polluted oft of yore,
From foule intemperance he oft did stay,
He oft finds present helpe, who does his griefe impart.
He washt them oft and oft, yet nought they beene
He washt them oft and oft, yet nought they beene
And oft approu'd in many hard assay,
To kindle oft assayd, but had no might;
And oft himselfe he chaunst to hurt vnwares,
Oft he re'nforst, and oft his forces fayld,
Oft he re'nforst, and oft his forces fayld,
Her oft to meet: which better to approue,
Full oft approu'd in many a cruell warre,
So hast thou oft with guile thine honour blent;
And falsed oft his blowes, t'illude him with such bayt.
Of his late wrongs, in which she oft him blamed
Witnesse the guiltlesse bloud pourd oft on ground,
Frayle men are oft captiu'd to couetise:
With yron toungs, and sprinckled oft the same
How oft do they, their siluer bowers leaue,
How oft do they with golden pineons, cleaue
Which oft the Paynim sau'd from deadly stowre.
But that too oft she chaung'd her natiue hew:
And oft when things were lost, or laid amis,
How oft that day did sad Brunchildis see
Yet oft the Briton kings against them strongly swayd.
Triumphed oft against her enimis;
Who hauing oft in battell vanquished
Yet oft annoyd with sundry bordragings
And oft of error did himselfe appeach:
For they haue oft drawne many a wandring wight
And with their wicked wings them oft did smight,
And straunge phantomes doth let vs oft forsee,
And oft of secret ill bids vs beware:
And oft inclining downe with kisses light,
Nor the fine nets, which oft we wouen see
She oft and oft aduiz'd him to refraine
She oft and oft aduiz'd him to refraine
So dischord oft in Musick makes the sweeter lay.
That oft out of her bed she did astart,
She oft did bath, and oft againe did dry;
She oft did bath, and oft againe did dry;
Then reasons reach, and oft hath wonders donne.
Things oft impossible (quoth she) seeme, ere begonne.
Their beames shall oft breake forth, that men them faire may see.
And boastfull men so oft abasht to heare?
Of Greekish bloud so oft in Troian plaine;
For thy she oft him counseld to forbeare
Yet many Ladies faire did oft complaine,
And oft his mother vewing his wide wound,
Full myld to her he spake, and oft let fall
And though oft looking backward, well she vewd,
Oft did he wish, that Lady faire mote bee
Doth praise thee oft, and oft from Stygian deepe
Doth praise thee oft, and oft from Stygian deepe
And oft him threatned death for his outrageous wrong.
Transformed oft, and chaunged diuerslie:
Oft from the forrest wildings he did bring,
And oft young birds, which he had taught to sing
That almost in the backe he oft her strake:
So oft as I this history record,
Ne paine at all; for he so oft had tryde
The powre thereof, and lou'd so oft in vaine,
Oft purposes, oft riddles he deuysd,
Oft purposes, oft riddles he deuysd,
When one so oft a night did ring his matins bell.
How oft for Venus, and how often eek
And oft committed fowle Idolatree.
Be bold: she oft and oft it ouer-red,
Be bold: she oft and oft it ouer-red,
Such as false loue doth oft vpon him weare:
For loue in thousand monstrous formes doth oft appeare.
And from her head oft rent her snarled heare:
And to her selfe oft wisht like happinesse,
By which fraile youth is oft to follie led,
Which to his Critias, shaded oft from sunne,
That I with teares full oft doe pittie it,
By way of sport, as oft in maskes is knowen,
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
That each to other made, as oft befell.
And many a priuate oft doth ouerthrow.
That oft for her in bloudie armes they fought.
Approued oft in perils manifold,
And had in many a battell oft bene tride,
Approued oft in many a perlous fight.
Full oft about her wast she it enclos'd;
And it as oft was from about her wast disclos'd.
Oft chaunging sides, and oft new place electing,
Oft chaunging sides, and oft new place electing,
And oft in wrath he thence againe vprose;
And oft in wrath he layd him downe againe.
But when in vaine to fight she oft assayd,
To banish sloth, that oft doth noble mindes annoy.
It so befell, as oft it fals in chace,
And made him oft, when he would strike, forbeare;
And oft admir'd his monstrous shape, and oft
And oft admir'd his monstrous shape, and oft
Him seemed oft he heard his owne right name.
And oft of them did earnestly inquire,
Vp to the throat, that oft with bitternesse
Both for great feeblesse, which did oft assay
And oft imbrast, as if that I were hee,
And kissing oft his visage pale and wan.
She, though full oft she both of them had seene
Yet inly groning deepe and sighing oft,
That in her cheekes made roses oft appeare:
Which fayled oft through faint and feeble plight:
The wanton Lee, that oft doth loose his way,
Oft tossed with his stormes, which therein still remaine.
And oft to grone with billowes beating from the maine.
That euen for griefe of minde he oft did grone,
Oft listening if he mote her heare againe;
So oft as I with state of present time,
For oft their lewdnes blotteth good deserts with blame.
It made her stagger oft, and stare with ghastly eye.
And bid him eate, henceforth he oft shall hungry sit.
And sooth oft seene, that proudest harts base loue hath blynded.
She thus oft times was beating off and on,
Oft did she blame her selfe, and often rew,
To shew that clemence oft in things amis,
Great warriours oft their rigour to represse,
Oft drew the Prince vnto his charret nigh,
Oft making offer him to smite, but found
Which she against the dred Mercilla oft did frame.
Oft spilles the principall, to saue the part;
They turne afresh, and oft renew their former threat.
That oft I driuen am to great distresse,
But th'Elfin swayne, that oft had seene like sight,
And stouped oft his head from shame to shield;
That oft he made him stagger as vnstayd,
And oft recuile to shunne his sharpe despight.
To wrong the weaker, oft falles in his owne assault.
Vnto the Knights, and calling oft for ayde;
And called oft with prayers loud and shrill,
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
To Gods sole grace, whom she did oft implore,
And oft complayn'd of fate, and Fortune oft defyde.
And oft complayn'd of fate, and Fortune oft defyde.
Hauing oft seene it tryde, as he did teach.
Him oft desired home with her to wend,
And proued oft in many perillous fight,
Make th'heauens tremble oft, & him with vowes asswage.
But that wylde man, whom though he oft forbad,
Is greatest shame: for oft it falles, that strong
Oft whip her dainty selfe, and much augment her doole.
So did these two this Knight oft tug and teare.
Now here, now there, and oft him neare he mist;
With such huge strokes, approued oft in fight,
And with sterne eye-browes stared at him oft,
And him did oft embrace, and oft admire,
And him did oft embrace, and oft admire,
And often did of loue, and oft of lucke complaine.
And oft reioyce, and oft for wonder shout,
And oft reioyce, and oft for wonder shout,
Which oft through pride do their owne perill weaue,
That made him scoule, and pout, and oft complaine
Was readie oft his owne hart to deuoure,
And oft, when Coridon vnto her brought
For who had tasted once (as oft did he)
With looks, with words, with gifts he oft her wowed;
Where wont the shepheards oft their pypes resound,
Oft cursing th'heauens, that so cruell were
And wishing oft, that he were present there,
Oft interlacing many a forged lie,
And often knockt his brest, as one that did repent.
The fearefull Shepheard often there aghast
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
He knocked fast, and often curst, and sware,
Wherein her face she often vewed fayne,
His cruell facts he often would repent;
Did often tremble at his horrid vew,
On which true Christians bloud was often spilt,
And holy Martyrs often doen to dye,
And with great griefe were often heard to grone,
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
In which his torment often was so great,
His ruefull shriekes and gronings, often tore
For God he often saw from heauens hight,
And often bounding on the brused gras,
And often blame the too importune fate,
And often semblaunce made to scape out of their hand.
To proofe of passing wonders hath full often vsd.
Ill by ensample good doth often gayne.
His force was vaine, and strooke more often wide,
With such faire slight him Guyon often faild,
Therein did often quench his thristy heat,
The crowned often slaine, the slayer cround,
In which she often vsd from open heat
And stretching forth his hand, did often thinke
And all his seed the curse doth often cleaue,
May often need the helpe of weaker hand;
She eke so often, as his life decayd,
Through which the damned ghosts doen often creepe
Did roll too highly, and too often glaunce,
That nought she did but wayle, and often steepe
To heare so often, in that royall hous,
And often waile their wealth, which he from them did keepe.
Tryde often to the scath of many deare,
(So from her often he had fled away,
But chaunged is, and often altred to and fro.
Yet pittie often did the gods relent,
There wont faire Venus often to enioy
And with sharpe threates her often did assaile,
Therein was writ, how often thundring Ioue
And often to him calling, to take surer hould.
How oft for Venus, and how often eek
That she may hearke to loue, and reade this lesson often.
The which most often end in bloudshed and in warre.
She in short space did often bring to nought
And their possessours often did dismay.
So hast thou to thy selfe false honour often wonne.
After he had so often wounded beene,
Is often seene full freshly to haue florisht,
Till hauing often by him stricken beene,
It often fals, (as here it earst befell)
But often did my folly fowle reproue.
Yet saw he often how he wexed glad,
And seeking often entraunce, afterwards in vaine.
Yet many doughty warriours, often tride
She often prayd, and often me besought,
She often prayd, and often me besought,
Yet often stainde with bloud of many a band
Yet loe the seas I see by often beating,
Full many Ladies often had assayd,
But he that had like tempests often tride,
Oft did she blame her selfe, and often rew,
(As often falles) of sundry things did commen.
And often treat for pardon and remission
It often fals in course of common life,
Who her imprisond hath, and her life often sought.
Therefore she vsed often to resort,
(Then answerd he) which often hath annoyd
Of a rude churle, whom often he accused
As their victorious deedes haue often showen,
And wretched sorrowes, which haue often hapt?
Yet he them all withstood, and often made relent.
And often him besought, and prayd, and vowd;
Him often scourg'd, and forst his feete to fynd:
Downe on his golden feete he often gazed,
And often did of loue, and oft of lucke complaine.
She made me often pipe and now to pipe apace.
To her, whose name he often did repeat;
Whose course is often stayd, yet neuer is astray.
Both which fraile men do oftentimes mistake,
That oftentimes he quakt, and fainted oftentimes.
That oftentimes he quakt, and fainted oftentimes.
Would oftentimes emongst them beare a part,
And oftentimes he would relent his pace,
And oftentimes great grones, and grieuous stounds,
And oftentimes loud strokes, and ringing sounds
Aloud to her he oftentimes did call,
That stratageme had oftentimes assayd
And oftentimes doe wish it neuer had bene writ.
That oftentimes vnquiet strife did moue
So oftentimes he out of sleepe abrayd,
Full oftentimes she leaue of him did take;
Full oftentimes did Britomart assay
For oftentimes faint hearts at first espiall
That oftentimes him nigh he ouerthrew:
Right true: but faulty men vse oftentimes
And made him oftentimes in field before me fall.
So stoutest knights doen oftentimes in field.
And certes it hath oftentimes bene seene,
And oftentimes by Turmagant and Mahound swore.
Such as the troubled Theaters oftimes annoyes.
Whose luring baytes oftimes doe heedlesse harts entyse.
Else should afflicted wights oftimes despeire.
That vnder shew oftimes of fayned semblance,
Oftimes it haps, that sorrowes of the mynd
Oftimes their sundry powres they did employ,
And plucke the pray oftimes out of their greedy hould.
As was his vse, ofttimes to visit me:
Oft-times amo[n]gst the wanton Nymphs to sport and toy.
Ancient Ogyges, even th'auncientest,
Cymochles; oh no, but Cymochles shade,
Furor, oh Furor hath me thus bedight:
Life and long health that gratious ointment gaue,
And his faire lockes, that wont with ointment sweet
With wicked herbes and ointments did besmeare
Vpon a snaggy Oke, which he had torne
The mossy braunches of an Oke halfe ded.
Then it had lighted on an aged Oke;
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine,
As when old father Nilus gins to swell
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
That here wex old in sleepe, whiles wicked wights
With sword in hand, and with the old man went;
Like the old ruines of a broken towre,
And lost an old foe, that did you molest:
Better new friend then an old foe is said.
A filthy foule old woman I did vew,
Where that old woman day and night did pray
That blind old woman and her daughter deare
Of that old woman tydings he besought,
And hoarie head of Archimago old,
For the old man well knew he, though vntold,
Were ruinous and old, but painted cunningly.
And strong aduizement of six wisards old,
Old loues, and warres for Ladies doen by many a Lord.
More old then Ioue, whom thou at first didst breede,
If old Aveugles sonnes so euill heare?
And the old cause of my continued paine
And after him old Ninus farre did pas
Whiles old Syluanus slept in shady arber sownd.
So towards old Syluanus they her bring;
And old Syluanus selfe bethinkes not, what
To do their seruice to Syluanus old,
Being in deed old Archimage, did stay
The subtill traines of Archimago old;
An old old man, with beard as white as snow,
An old old man, with beard as white as snow,
For as he forward moou'd his footing old,
And said, Old sire, it seemes thou hast not red
A loathly, wrinckled hag, ill fauoured, old,
Vnto old Timon he me brought byliue,
Old Timon, who in youthly yeares hath beene
But me had warnd old Timons wise behest,
Which still wex old in woe, whiles woe still wexeth new.
And all about old stockes and stubs of trees,
But thrust them forth still, as they wexed old:
Great grace that old man to him giuen had;
But now aread, old father, why of late
The knight with that old Dragon fights
Great ioy was made that day of young and old,
Then turning to his Palmer said, Old syre
Yet cold through feare, and old conceiued dreads;
There this old Palmer shewed himselfe that day,
For he was wylie witted, and growne old
Thus said; Old man, great sure shalbe thy meed,
And eke her face ill fauourd, full of wrinckles old.
The sonnes of old Acrates and Despight,
With silly weake old woman thus to fight.
Vpon the old, him stirring to be wroke
To ferry that old man ouer the perlous foord.
Him when the old man saw, he wondred sore,
Well it appeared, to haue beene of old
But ouergrowne with dust and old decay,
Those were the two sonnes of Acrates old
Foolish old man, said then the Pagan wroth,
By whose aduise old Priams cittie fell,
That chamber seemed ruinous and old,
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
And therein sate an old old man, halfe blind,
Of old Assaracus, and Inachus diuine.
And old records from auncient times deriu'd,
And that old man Eumnestes, by their propertis.
And old diuision into Regiments,
Thy fathers and great Grandfathers of old,
As in that old mans booke they were in order told.
From royall stocke of old Assaracs line,
Therefore old Syre thy course do thereunto apply.
And his braue shield, full of old moniments,
As it in bookes hath written bene of old.
In which there written was with cyphers old,
And that old Dame said many an idle verse,
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
All night in old Tithonus frosen bed,
But her old Nourse was nought dishartened,
That one of th'old Heroes seemes to bee:
His dreaded head, and the old sparkes renew
Th'old woman nought, that needed, did omit;
In th'euening late old Glauce thither led
Bad her old Squire vnlace her lofty creast;
Till that old Glauce gan with sharpe repriefe,
Breeder of new, renewer of old smarts:
It sited was in fruitfull soyle of old,
Th'one faire and fresh, the other old and dride:
Old Genius the porter of them was,
Old Genius, the which a double nature has.
So like a wheele around they runne from old to new.
In which there slept a fisher old and pore,
And felt in his old courage new delight
Thereat th'old man did nought but fondly grin,
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
But that old leachour, which with bold assault
Saue one old Nymph, hight Panope to keepe it cleane.
But he is old, and withered like hay,
Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
Against that nation, from whose race of old
And Troynouant was built of old Troyes ashes cold.
Till he with old Latinus was constraind,
Corineus, and Coulin of Debon old
Old Mnemon. Therefore Sir, I greet you well
Which th'old man seeing well, who too long thought
To take to his new loue, and leaue her old despysd.
Or care of credite, or of husband old,
Soone as the old man saw Sir Paridell,
The old man could not fly, but fell to ground halfe ded.
Her old Malbecco, which did her vpbrayd,
And therefore gan aduize with her old Squire,
Of louers sad calamities of old,
She old and crooked were, yet now of late,
He now vnable was to wreake his old despight.
As old and crooked and not good for ought.
And both of old well knowing by their names,
And of all old dislikes they made faire weather,
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
And that old aged Dame, his faithfull Squire,
And this old woman here remaining beene;
Through helpe (quoth she) of this old woman here
But one old woman sitting there beside,
But when the world woxe old, it woxe warre old
But when the world woxe old, it woxe warre old
Of his old loue, conceau'd in secret brest,
For old despight, which now forth newly brake
In which old Styx her aged bones alway,
Old Styx the Grandame of the Gods, doth lay.
By whom those old Heroes wonne such fame;
Phoenix, and Aon, and Pelasgus old,
Into old Gall, that now is cleeped France,
Old Tethys, th'oldest two of all the rest,
Proud Priams towne. So wise is Nereus old,
Old Cybele, arayd with pompous pride,
That if old sawes proue true (which God forbid)
That to old Loncaster his name doth lend;
All these the daughters of old Nereus were,
Of his old hurt, which was not throughly cured.
That it was no old sore, which his new paine procured.
Whether old Proteus true or false had sayd,
And if to those ï¿½gyptian wisards old,
And next to him old Saturne, that was wont be best.
In those old times, of which I doe intreat,
To follow his old quest, the which him forth did call.
For his huge club, which had subdew'd of old
And token true to old Eumenias,
Of th'old ï¿½gyptian Kings, that whylome were;
Mote in them stirre vp old rebellious thought,
First was a sage old Syre, that had to name
He brought forth that old hag of hellish hew,
The whyles Sir Artegall, with that old knight
But yet old Sergis did so well him paine,
When as two old ill fauour'd Hags he met,
Since I was ten yeares old, now growen to stature strong.
So well and wisely did that good old Knight
And that old Knight by all meanes did assay,
Or deare aby, for why his Lord of old
Of those old Gyants, which did warres darraine
Then came to them a good old aged syre,
Yet was not so, but as old stories tell
But Meliboee (so hight that good old man)
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
Old loue is litle worth when new is more prefard.
They spoyld old Melibee of all he had,
Then forth the good old Meliboe was brought,
Old Meliboe is slaine, and him beside
Old Meliboe and his good wife withall
So did those olde Heroes hereof taste,
Old Tethys, th'oldest two of all the rest,
And the old-woman carefully displayd
The fruitfull Oliue, and the Platane round,
Do worship her, as Queene, with oliue girlond cround.
And winnes an Oliue girlond for her meeds:
And both were with one oliue garland crownd,
Adornd with fruitfull Oliues all arownd,
To weet the mighty Ollyphant, that wrought
Britomart chaceth Ollyphant,
It was that Ollyphant, the brother deare
Vpon the top of Mount Olympus hight,
Th'old woman nought, that needed, did omit;
Was there, and all that nature did omit,
A Gentle Knight was pricking on the plaine,
But on his brest a bloudie Crosse he bore,
High on an hill, his flocke to vewen wide,
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
And proou'd your strength on a strong enimie,
So forward on his way (with God to frend)
The drouping Night thus creepeth on them fast,
As messenger of Morpheus on them cast
And on his litle winges the dreame he bore
On earthly braunch, the daughter of a king,
And that false other Spright, on whom he spred
But now seemde best, the person to put on
A bloudy crosse, and on his crauen crest
And like a Persian mitre on her hed
Their horned fronts so fierce on either side
Curse on that Crosse (quoth then the Sarazin)
On silly Dame, subiect to hard mischaunce,
Say on Fradubio then, or man, or tree,
And a dull blast, that breathing on her face,
Till on a day (that day is euery Prime,
He set her on her steede, and forward forth did beare.
And on the grasse her daintie limbes did lay
That on her shoulders sad a pot of water bore.
For on his backe a heauy load he bare
